bib.title: Cross-section measurement for the 10B(n,alpha)7Li reaction at 4.0 and 5.0MeV

free_txt: Experiments were performed at the 4.5MV
Van de Graaff accelerator of Peking University
SD, LV.
A gridded ionization chamber (GIC) was used as
the charged particle detector. It has the advantages
of high detection efficiency (close to 100%), large
detection solid angle (almost 2Pi), the ability of
particle energy and direction determination and the
potential of discrimination of different particles.
A BF3 long counter was used as a neutron flux
monitor.
The main sources of error of the cross-section
value are:
uncertainty in background subtraction
uncertainty in the 238U fission cross-section
uncertainty in the 238U fission count
uncertainty in the atom number of the 10B sample
uncertainty in the atom number of the
238U sample
Total error is about 8%.
Experiments were performed at the 4.5MV
Van de Graaff accelerator of Peking University
Neutrons were produced through the D(d,n)3He
reaction with a deuterium gas target. The length of
the gas cell was 2.0 cm and the pressure of the
deuterium gas was 3.0-2.87 atm with a molybdenum
foil window 5 mm in thickness separated from the
vacuum tube. The energies of the deuteron beam
before enter the foil were 1.77 and 2.44 MeV, and
the neutron energies were 4.0 and 5.0 MeV, with
energy spreads 0.22 and 0.16 MeV, respectively. The
estimated neutron fluxes on the sample were 2.1x10**5
and 2.5x10**5 n/s/cm2 for the above-mentioned two
neutron energy measurements.
data were taken from ENDF/B-VI.8
A 10B sample and a 238U foil were set back-to-back
at the common cathode. The 10B sample was evaporated
on a tantalum backing 4.8 cm in diameter and 50 mm
in thickness. The abundance of the 10B isotope was
94.0%. The mass of the 10B sample was 514 mu-g, and
the thickness was 34.7 mu-g/cm2. The mass and the
diameter of the 238U sample were 7.85+-0.10 mg and
4.50 cm, and the abundance of the 238U isotope was
from the abstract of ref.
